I changed the code block as follows:

  bool result = false;

  // Get the gui.ini path environment variable
  char *guiINIPath = getenv("GAZEBO_GUI_INI_PATH");
  char *home = getenv("HOME");

  boost::filesystem::path path;
  // If the environment variable was not specified
  if (guiINIPath)
  {
    path = guiINIPath;
  }
  else if (home)
  {
    // Check the home directory
    // Construct the path to gui.ini
    path = home;
    path = path / ".gazebo" / "gui.ini";
  }
  if (path.empty())
  {
    gzerr << "Neither HOME nor GAZEBO_GUI_INI_PATH environment variables were\
              found. Unable to locate gui.ini." << std::endl;
  }
  else
  {
    gzmsg << "Loading .ini file from: " << path << std::endl;
    if (!(result=gui::loadINI(path)))
    {
      gzerr << "Unable to read ~/.gazebo/gui.ini file from " << path <<"."
                                                             << std::endl;
    } 
    else
    {
      gzmsg << "Loaded .ini file from: " << path << std::endl;
    }
  }

However, when I set GAZEBO_GUI_INI_PATH to something like "this_file_does_not_exist", loadINI does not return false and get the gzmsg "Loaded .ini file from this_file_does_not_exist".

I'm investigating the implementation of loadINI right now, and I'll commit the changes when the behavior is correct.

It looks like loadINI creates a file with the requested name when the input filename does not exist. I'll add a gzmsg telling the user that a file is being created, assuming we want to keep this behavior. I think I would prefer it to create a file if the default location was specified, but throw an error if GAZEBO_GUI_INI_PATH is bogus.
